So one of the two main birds royally pissed me off by giving me a 42 in the scoring of their final level when the average per level in Battle of the Birds is more than a hundred usually, and I decided beforehand "whoever wins, wins" so I went on with the game as normal not knowing it didn't mean the boss fight after that phone call would be with the winner, not the (probably very sore) loser, but I continued playing, figuring I'd rather finish the game than go back for my revenge for a mere 42 point total on a level. I unlock Bow Kid and remember that there's a file select so I go back in there and speedrun the game until I can get to the boss battle I so crave. Here's the thing about why this preface is important to the review: none of replaying it felt like a chore because "uuugh, I've seen all this already, get on with it! where's the skip tutorial button? skip cutscene and get me to where I need to be", I still found myself slowing down to appreciate the game and the characters within, even the character that I was SO excited to beat up was worth slowing down some just because even with that little bump, he's still such a fun character and worth every second I took to just enjoy. 
I'm also glad to say that beating the troublesome level the second time as Bow Kid went a lot smoother. I didn't need to do any grinding to make sure that I got the right bird to win and it was actually close this time, but it probably also helped that I went after an achievement the second time that was with the other bird that I imagine would lower the score greatly lol still convinced it's rigged in his favor
The only thing that changed from play through one and play through two was who I was playing as and I was still so excited to go through all the levels again, that's to say nothing of how fun it was the first time around. tiny kid goes on adventure to get pieces of time back, before having to fight a crackhead who wanted to steal all of said pieces "for justice".

levels are as followed

Sardinia (mafia town)
Texas/Hollywood (battle of the birds)
Louisiana (subcon forest)
Switzerland (alpine skyline)

Before you finally brawl with the punk who stole your pieces in a big castle in hell.
Very simple story, and not too hard. I dont have the DLCS but they look good and ive heard positive things.

Then we have the mods. Ranging from short and simple, to entire fanmade acts and chapters. Some are boss fights, and some are shitposts. Either way, you have plenty of options after finishing the story.

8.7/10  30 bucks is  a decent price for a modern supported 3d platformer that has built in mod support and easy access to said mods.

148982855.review:
Huh, never wrote a review for this game. Funny, considering it's one of the best games I've ever played.

A Hat in Time was one of the first games I bought on Steam, mainly because I had only really played the Switch version and I really wanted to try out the game's modding scene. Turns out, that was probably one of the best gaming decisions I have ever made.

The vanilla game was already amazing, I love games that focus heavily on characters and the fact nearly EVERYTHING is voice acted gives them so much life. Hat Kid also controls VERY well, the physics are somewhat floaty but you can do some absolutely insane platforming tricks, especially if you equip the no-bonk badge. You could probably spend hours just playing around in one of the game's major levels and figuring out new parkour tricks. Speaking of the levels, despite there being only a few main areas they never overstay their welcome and offer tons of exploration outside of the main objectives. The game just feels good to play, both aesthetically and mechanically.

And then you open up the workshop.

This game was already a 10/10 from the start, but then they gave the community an easy way to make their own additions and it becomes a 20/10. The amount of insanely high-quality mods people have made for this game is absolutely mind-blowing, and has likely contributed the most to the amount of hours I've played A Hat in Time. The fact the modding tools are so easy to access also means it's much easier for new modders to join the scene, usually with cosmetic mods that allow the player to update their look. I definitely took the opportunity to make a few (okay, a LOT of) playable character mods, and while they are FAR from perfect it's still so cool to see them work in-game. I may not interact much with the bulk of the Hat in Time community, but you guys are awesome. You're the reason this game has endless content.

The amount of memories I have with this game are something I could never replace, whether from playing around in online party, creating playable characters that somehow eventually made me a moderator for a Youtuber, or just messing around with whatever new thing the modders created. Gears For Breakfast made a special game, one that has brought in so much creativity from developers and modders alike and one that I'll probably still be playing years from now.

This is a cute, decently playable platformer.  It's cartoon graphics are pleasing to look at, but the fidelity could be better by modern standards.  It doesn't quite have the professional cel shaded look that bigger developers can pull off.  The music is pretty good, and reminds me of other games' music (in a good way).  There are a few quirks, like the environments being a little too claustrophobic for the camera's liking (turn off top down view completely), and some hitboxes being misleading on enemy attacks, but it's not really a precise game, so it's not a big deal.  I do wish the loading times were better though, much better looking games load much faster on my SSD.

Overall though, it's worth a purchase when it goes on sale.  I got a particularly good deal on the ultimate edition, $20.  For that price, I can definitely recommend it.

148426243.review:
[h1] A Hat in Time: A Charming and Enjoyable Platformer [/h1]

A Hat in Time, an indie 3D platformer initially funded through Kickstarter, made a successful debut on the Nintendo Switch. While the base game has been well-received on other platforms, the Switch version offers several reasons to dive into this charming title.

Firstly, A Hat in Time is an excellent fit for the Switch, offering on-the-go gameplay. Its short, engaging levels cater to both quick sessions and longer playthroughs. The Joy-Con controllers work well with the gameplay, although the camera can be problematic, a common issue in 3D platformers.

The Nintendo Switch release includes the "Seal the Deal" DLC. This DLC introduces "The Arctic Cruise," a new level set on a cruise ship run by seals and piloted by a walrus. While it adds to the game's content, some players might find it a bit short with only two acts before the final boss. Additionally, to access this level, you need to collect a substantial number of timepieces.

The DLC also brings "Death Wish," a challenging mode with various demanding tasks. Completing these tasks earns Death Tokens, which are required to progress in "The Arctic Cruise." While "Death Wish" is fun, some of the challenges are incredibly tough, leading to moments of frustration.

One issue with this DLC package is the integration of "Death Wish" with "The Arctic Cruise." You can't continue in the cruise level without completing certain "Death Wish" challenges, which disrupts the game's flow. Given the difficulty of these challenges, some players might find this connection frustrating.

A Hat in Time on the Switch does suffer from long loading times and significant framerate drops in certain sections, which can affect the gameplay experience. These issues may not be as pronounced on other platforms where the game has been released.

In summary, A Hat in Time remains a charming and enjoyable platformer. While the Nintendo Switch version adds value with the included DLC, some integration issues between the DLC and the base game, along with technical problems, slightly mar the experience. However, the game's delightful charm, engaging levels, and nostalgic 3D platforming make it a worthwhile addition to the Switch or Steamdeck library.

147341690.review:
My score for this one is 6.5/10. If I could give a middle thumb, then I would. 

I'm really torn on this game. I really liked it, and recommend it to others. Especially if you like more tech based platformers. Although, it does also have some flaws that really drag the game down for me. 

It's a cute game that wears its inspirations on its sleeves. Sometimes this treads more on the grounds of copying something rather than simply referencing or adapting it. Most of this is perfectly fine though and add something to the game that feels familiar yet unique. The movement and moment to moment game play itself feel clean. I was constantly engaged with my inputs. Moving around being incredibly fun to do. Exploration and finding secrets reward good movement, this encourages you to develop better skills with movement. One issue I found with the game play itself was the camera. Sometimes it would jerk your focus in a certain direction when it really didn't need to. Other times it wouldn't do it at all when it really should have. Sometimes it was very finicky to work around. Getting zoomed in on in certain areas which really hurt my ability to tell where I was going or what I was doing. 

The visual design is what I believe to be my favorite aspect of A Hat in Time. The designers really killed it here. Developing a world that was constantly interesting to look at and engage with. The way everything looked and felt really helped me to feel like my actions were meaningful in the world itself. Themes varied per world and per level, but always kept a nice humorous and cute nature to them. The game in this sense knows itself and what it wants to be. The characters all had designs to them that fit their area nicely. The only issue I had with them was the lack of characters. The game is very short and as such, doesn't feature all too many characters. Not a super big issue, I know. I just loved all the people I met, and wanted to meet even more

I like the hats and badges, but don't really understand why some exist the way they do. There are a few hats in the game, but I only ended up using about two of them on the regular. I like the designs and alternate looks for these hats, but their functions are highly underutilized for a game called "A Hat in Time". Badges are a neat little addition to the game's mechanics. But there are a couple that really confuse me. The hook and beam shot specifically. The beam shot feels like something that would've made a really cool hat, but ended up as an optional badge instead. I feel like this is a huge loss of potential. The hook shot is one that I really take issue with. For an optional badge, you use it incredibly often. To the point where not having it on felt wrong. At that point it might as well just be a base mechanic instead of a badge. 

The next few paragraphs enter into spoiler territory so check it out at your own discretion. They are about story and pacing.

[spoiler] The pacing of the game is something I got confused by. In order to complete Acts 1 and 2, you need to use things that you unlock in Acts 3 and 4. Disrupting those stories and sending you forward to new ones. This threw off the flow of the game by a huge margin. I was really invested in Act 2's story when I was suddenly forced to go to Act 3 to get the necessary item for completing Act 2. This item of course was the hook badge. I then became invested in Act 3 and finished that before going back to Act 2, where I had lost most of my interest in the story. This happens again, albeit not as bad in Act 1. In this act you need a new hat from Act 4 in order to do a single level. Felt weird needing to come back to an act that I left behind hours ago just to finish it. The level itself is also super short anyways so it felt like my chain was being yanked a bit. [/spoiler]

[spoiler] The story itself is pretty eh. It's interesting at first with the Mustache Girl and Hat Kid taking on the Mafia. It sets up a pretty interesting plot that gets thrown out the minute Mustache Girl becomes your enemy. She doesn't come back until you get 25 hourglasses. This is more than half of what's available, but it feels pretty lackluster since you can hit that before even touching Act 4. I feel like getting 30 or even 35 hourglasses would've made more sense. Some sub stories were really interesting. Such as Act 2's bird movie maker battle and Act 3's soul contracts. Others were completely nonexistent and just really boring. Act 4's being the worst of the two mediocre ones. Act 4 itself is something I could live without. It was a slog to get through and is the only level that I genuinely felt was wasting my time. It abandons the usual level setup for a free roam approach which I found to be more annoying than interesting. Especially when I went back in to find the sub area entrances. It just took forever to finish and a lot of that was because you do so much walking and waiting in that Act. [/spoiler]

All in all. A Hat in Time is a good platformer. It's not without its issues though. I really feel like this game needed some more time in the oven. With a bit more time and love it could've been something a lot better. But as it is, it's fine. Community maps are really cool and are what I'll likely come back to the game to do. I don't see myself replaying the base game though. One last thing I want to mention is that the game balances its cute yet serious nature well. It does fall apart here and there though. There are times where it teeters a little too far in one direction. These events are small and don't ruin the game at all. They just made me feel weird when they showed up. Like I was listening to a self insert comment from one of the developers themselves, but not the good kind. Took me out of the game a bit. Again, not too bad, but it wasn't welcome when it happened. 

Try this one out if you like platformers. I will say though, do not try and do all of Act 4 in one go. The fun I was having quickly flew away after the first hourglass. 

TL/DR: Game good, has issues. Play it if you like to jump on things.

146978132.review:
[h1]Hat in Time Review[/h1]
[h2]A Decepticon's Perspective[/h2]

[b]Graphics:[/b]
The graphics in Hat in Time are like comparing a Seeker's speed to a Ground Pounder's plodding. They have a certain [i]retro charm[/i], reminiscent of the Cybertronian cartoons from eons past. While not as dazzling as an energon-infused laser beam, they do their job.

[u]Gameplay:[/u]
The nimble protagonist darts around the game worlds like a Seeker in battle, collecting those precious "timepieces" with an almost Starscream level of determination. The worlds are as diverse as our varied Decepticon forces, and the missions offer a [i]decent challenge[/i].

[b]Story:[/b]
The story is no epic struggle for the AllSpark, but it serves its purpose. The characters are functional, much like Soundwave's drones, but lack that true Decepticon flair.

[spoiler]And let's not forget the puny humans you encounter. They're about as insignificant as organic life can be, but hey, they serve their purpose.[/spoiler]

[hr][/hr]

All in all, Hat in Time is like an energon cube: small, but it'll keep you entertained for a while. I'd give it a Starscream rating of [b]7/10[/b], purely because it manages to capture a hint of that '80s nostalgia that I, Starscream, naturally appreciate.

146783694.review:
I can understand why this game has so many positive reviews as it is appears very appealing visually and in a gameplay sense is reminiscent of older classic 3d-platormer / collectathon games, the most popular comparisons seem to be super mario 64 and banjo kazooie. You will definitely feel the similarities as you play especially with the main progression exactly the same as Mario 64 in that you jump in to a decently sized free-roam are and have to collect a certain thing by doing a task such as reaching the top of a tree or something like sneaking around a haunted house. it's pretty much identical in that sense. For me I think that was an issue as when comparing it to other really good platformers I thought it was quite lacking even though it's a good game in it's own right which is why I have given it a positive review. 
    The graphics are very pretty and the game looks really nice especially some of the later levels, the music really fits the locations too I thought and it really does feel as though the sounds fit the location very nicely for most of the levels. There are upbeat and happy tunes as well as some more sinister sounding ones which really fit the vibe well. I will say that there was some flickering and screen tearing at certain parts but no other issues visually. The platforming, (the major part of the gameplay) was really good as well with some minor exceptions where I felt it to be slightly unresponsive with grabbing onto ledges and the wall running feature. There is a nice balance with most of the game being quite easy overall but there are a few areas which might take a couple of tries plus there are also loads of bonus challenges for you to complete which scale the difficulty up even more. Something that surprised me was how good the hat system was used in certain areas and I really enjoyed how they've made the hat system which a major part of the platforming where you have to constantly switch hats for different areas of a level. There is a story to the game which is nothing special of course and some of the dialogue is quite cringey at times. It's just a cute looking platformer/collectathon game with some cool mechanics that will definitely hit you with some nostalgia. 
    However, my experience was slightly diminished by me constantly comparing it to other games which isn't the games fault of course as personal biases can always affect ones perception of things so I feel I should mention that as I didn't feel that it brought anything new to it's genre that hadn't been done before and better I should add.

146408187.review:
This game has been on my radar since I first watched Shenpai play it. The music was incredible and the character designs fantastical, but there was one thing preventing me from playing.

It was a platformer.

Platformers have always made me feel inferior because of my lack of depth perception, so I tended to keep my distance. So, choosing to finally play this game, especially by myself, was a step out of my comfort zone. But I am so glad that I played it.

Starting with the base game, I was pleasantly surprised to find the platforming to be easy to learn. Most of the mistakes made early on were due to my own learning curve of using the Xbox controller (accidentally pressing Y instead of X because they’re flipped on other controllers). Each of the base four worlds (five if counting the final boss) had its own unique characters, quirks, music, parkour, puzzles, and boss fights. All of the worlds (except one but I’ll talk about that one in a second) follow a similar world and level formula to Mario 64. Once you collect the item at the end of the level, you get sent back to the home base and are able to select another level.

However…there is one black sheep world…Alpine Skyline. It is the largest world and is listed as a Free Roam. I collected one item and decided to not go back to it because of how long it took to get said item. Since the world was so large it took forever to get anywhere and the platforming had a large difficulty jump. (Thankfully the developers learned from this when it came to the DLC, but I’ll get to that).

I’ll try to talk about the end without spoiling anything. It combines not only every skill you’ve learned through the game but also the characters you’ve met along the way. The game ties it all into a neat little bow and concludes it all in a very satisfying way.

Now to the DLC. The very first thing I encountered when it came to the DLC was the online multiplayer. Seeing as how it’s been out for a while I was excited to try it out, but oh my god the glitches. The game broke in so many different ways with two people, and it’s unfortunate because not everyone can play together on a console or on the same computer.

When it comes to the Seal the Deal portion of the DLC, I chose to save it for a later day. From what I could tell, it is a challenging world and mode added and I didn’t really want to subject myself to that. The seals are cute though!

The jewel of all the DLC has to be the Nyakuza Metro. Oh my god it is amazing. It was another Free Roam, but I feel it was done right. The music was like the base game’s but on steroids. No specific area was the wrong way to go and exploration was highly rewarded. It wasn’t too big and every place was connected. This world had to be my favorite overall despite its challenges. (No it wasn’t because of the Metro Cats i swear).

Overall, if you’re looking for a game that is friendly to those new to platforming, this one is definitely it. And if you’re looking for a challenge, the DLC can match that as well. I thoroughly enjoyed this game, and I hope others do as well.

145990287.review:
I can respect and appreciate all the hard work and time the developers spent on this 3D platformer game, but after playing for a sizable number of hours, I don't think it lives up to the hype that led me to buying this game after finishing Spyro Reignited.

For me, 3D platformer games are a tricky thing to enjoy, as game balance and game feel is directly tied to the movement mechanics and how they're applied to the game's platforming challenges.

And I didn't like the general gameplay loop of A Hat in Time, as it often felt frustrating to complete the platforming segments instead of rewarding and cathartic. The murder mystery segment was a little funny, but it was very difficult to feel a strong connection to the characters and the setting. Collecting time pieces isn't as satisfying as collecting stars in Super Mario Galaxy.

I had a lot of fun with Super Mario Galaxy and Super Mario Galaxy 2 years ago because the platforming mechanics and challenges were satisfying to overcome, and the space odyssey setting was visually dazzling and memorable, with a surprisingly number of deep and impactful themes about the circle of life and rebirth.

Perhaps that led to me having higher expectations for what makes a good 3D platformer, as I feel that various other platformers such as Spyro Reignited and Blue Fire and even Super Mario 64/DS aren't as good as Super Mario Galaxy 1/2.

145670600.review:
I'm only 30 minutes in and I already love this purchase. It's like a colorful N64 game, but with voice acting and cutesy characters.

Edit: I finished the game after 12 hours with 26 out of 40 time pieces. The game is pretty easy and kid-friendly to beat, with bosses that were too easy for me and no challenging minions. But the platforming for the optional treasures provided rewarding challenges if you're more experienced with platformers.

Thoughts on the level design:

The first level was hands-down the most fun to explore and the most polished, and it made it worth buying. (No, you don't fight mafia goons the whole game, as the early access videos led me to believe.)  Side note: I wished Mafia Town had some undersea sections, since I was excited when I discovered you could turn into a statue and use your extra weight to dive under water, but was let down when I found the mechanic wasn't used and there wasn't much anything to collect under the piers.

I didn't care as much for the film studio aesthetic of the second level, or the Metal Gear Solid style stealth, but I had enough time pieces to skip playing it after the Owl Express (which I was my most hated level.) 

The third level had some challenging optional platforming in the trees above the level for collectibles that nearly form a second half of the level that you can skip. You probably won't appreciate until you're a couple of hours in. The villain made even the duller task-making fun.

The fourth level had challenging platforming which I liked.

Though the game started to feel rushed by the 4th level because they didn't bother to write in any story or characters.

I didn't enjoy the final boss fight which was too easy for me, and as someone who played many platformers and collectathons over the years I wish there was at least another more challenging optional boss. I also felt cheated by how other characters you met in the game suddenly behaved differently. 

Overall, the platforming and exploration carried the game, and despite some rough patches,. I can recommend it. I'm glad they focused on quality and avoided forcing you to backtrack constantly or having to constantly collect as many non-essential items as in Donkey Kong 64.

145410154.review:
After only really having watched a lot of this game on Youtube, I finally played it for myself when I got it as part of the recent Humble Bundle. I don't do many reviews, but I feel like it this time for whatever reason, so here goes.

This game is pretty much exactly what it says on the tin; a 'cute-as-heck 3D platformer'. The controls are good, the platforming feels good... but the most unique and special part of this otherwise rather generic platformer are the incredibly varied themes and scenarios the levels take place in.

You start off crashing down into Mafia Town, which is mainly inhabited by identical-looking, dumb talking, and overly aggressive mafia men. From there, you go from acting on the sets of a bird-run movie studio, to signing your soul away and doing errand work in a haunted forest, and more.

The various hats that you can stitch together in the game all have unique abilities, but these abilities are, honestly, mostly pretty basic and generic, feeling like they should've been a part of the base moveset. The Dweller's Mask gets some creative usage, however, and the Time Stop Hat is fun to mess around with.

Scattered throughout the game's levels are special 'Time Rifts', challenge stages with much more demanding platforming than the main levels. While being a bit of a pain to find just by the photo sometimes, they're a fun little slice of challenge in an otherwise rather easy game.

As good as it is, however, I do have one major gripe with this game; it's too [i]short[/i]. There's four 'chapters', consisting of multiple 'acts' each, and there are 40 total 'Time Pieces', the main collectible of the game. The content you get here with the base game, while quality, is unfortunately rather limited. Expect to spend about 12-14 hours on a non-rushed, fairly thorough first playthrough.

But, well, when my only real complaint is the length of the game... well, that's really speaking to the quality of the content on offer here. I'm planning to get Nyakuza Metro soon, as I've heard good things about it, and I haven't gotten too into the Steam Workshop content yet, so you could get a lot more out of this game with both of those.

Do I recommend A Hat In Time overall? Yes, but be aware of the short length of the game before you make the purchase, and maybe consider waiting for a sale. If the length doesn't bother you, though, then there's really no reason NOT to get it. It's a fun, cute throwback 3D platformer that sets itself apart from the rest with its settings and characters. Thumbs up!

Just beat the game, haven't touch extra contents yet. It's a solid game. Fun world, fun characters. And most of all, it's nice that the character are so expressive. It genuinely feels like you're a kid again. 

The gameplay, for the most part, are great. Basic movement feels fluid. The hats that gives you power are good, except the ice ground pound; that one is not utilize well enough. I wish we have more stamp (which grant passive abilities). I feel like I get the best stamp before I even finished half of the game. Maybe that's on purpose but I prefer more. 

The biggest fault is some level are not well designed. At times, checkpoint are unnecessarily punishing. The hats that points you to the objective barely help because it just zoom you into specific direction. The worse of all are when I landed on a specific platform perfectly fine, yet the game defined me as hurt/dead. I get it, I'm not supposed to be there I guess, but if players are not supposed to be there, then make it so that it's impossible for players to be there to begin with. Punishing players is for your mistake is stupid. 

Still I had fun playing this game, and I recommend it. On sale.

144110246.review:
Una gran experiencia - 10/10

Como jugador casual me es difícil sentirme inmerso o fascinado (la gran mayoría de veces) con un juego. A Hat In Time es sin dudas un juego que la verdad me sorprendió bastante, se ve la clara inspiración de Undertarle y Mario Galaxy en ciertas partes lo cual hace ver que este proyecto es uno hecho con amor. Con un sountrack increíble y su comedia ingeniosa puedo afirmar que es un gran juego, y sin dudas, mi indie favorito después de Undertale  y Coffee Talk. 

Lo malo, claro, es que llega a ser un poco repetitivo y mas con los "Time Rift". Mafia Town, aunque no es un mal lugar para comenzar nuestra aventura puede llegar a ser abrumadora para personas que no están tan acostumbradas a este tipo de juegos, y mas importante aun, este mismo episodio llego a abrumarme con todas las cosas que puedes recolectar y juntar,  mas que nada por la falta de direcciones a seguir para saber que hacer. 

Dejando de lado eso (y como ya había mencionado) es un gran juego y puedo asegurarte que vale completamente la pena. Si disfrutas de juegos de aventura, exploración y de ser libre de golpear a diestra y siniestra a los npcs, A HAT IN TIME es para ti :)

143833325.review:
A Hat in Time is among the best 3D platformers to release in the modern age. It has an excellent and unrelenting sense of humor; it has fun and engaging level designs; and the gameplay is enjoyable and accessible while also surprisingly deep.

The art direction is also excellent. The games looks gorgeous if you can crank the graphics up, and lower settings allow the game to run on a potato without compromising the style. The soundtrack consistently fits in perfectly with the levels, and is good enough to come back to even long after you're done with the game.

The dev team clearly understood the appeal of classic 3D platformers and wanted to recreate that experience, and their passion and care shines in every corner.

143614913.review:
[h1]I wish I played this sooner[/h1]

There's no real way to describe this game. It's a collectathon that brings me back to my childhood days of Banjo-Kazooie and Mario Sunshine. This game is funny, fun to play, and you just have to love the characters. Look at the overwhelming response in reviews of this game, just trust them and try this game out for yourself.

[h1]The Good:[/h1]
[list]
    [*][u]The hilarity![/u] This game thrives off of being funny. The first world, Mafia World, is what instantly sold me on this game. So many unexpected things happened that made me and my partner laugh, we found ourselves taking time through missions just to see the level and hear what the characters had to say. Even when there were dark moments or themes, it usually had humor to it. A talking noose that complimented your neck? It's silly!
    [*][u]Unique levels and characters[/u]. Each level was different in theme and had plenty of characters to enjoy a storyline with. From a spooky forest, to mountaintops above the clouds, to a movie studio involving trains. I guarantee that there's at least one level that appeals to each and every person. As well as a favorite character. There's even an optional way to see the backstory of most characters. I now see the hype and why everyone loves The Conductor so much. (Though The Snatcher was definitely my favorite)
    [*][u]Music and sound design was wonderful[/u]. Each soundtrack fit the mood or theme of the level and mission that was playing. Already, I find myself planning on using the soundtrack to play in the background while I do things around the house.
    [*][u]Online content spans far and wide[/u]. I didn't get a chance to do multiplayer or many workshop / mod things, but I did a handful of creative levels that mocked old Mario games. It was impressive how well they were done, and I look forward to seeing more of what can be done by users for online content in the future.
    [*][u]Customization[/u]. I love that, if you didn't like the way your character looked, you had plenty of options to change it. Different hat designs, clothes, clothing colors, weapons, and even stickers to collect that you can play around with. Not to mention that you could get mods to change your preferences even further, for full customization.
    [*][u]Controls / Mechanics were simple[/u]. The controls were not complex, I'd go so far to say, they were fun to control, even if a little on the "floaty" side that some people might disagree with. Switching from hat to hat (abilities) was instant and easy to select, and the controls don't require frustrating button combos to memorize for basic gameplay.
[/list]
[h1]The Neutral / Bad:[/h1]
[list]
    [*][u]Shorter than expected, should be lower in price[/u]. I'm sad that the base game was as short as it was, but I'd say the game would be better to get on sale. It was fun and I myself am happy with my purchase, but it's definitely priced a little too high for what it is. There is DLC, but it's priced so cheaply that those are well worth the price. Not to mention there is plenty of Workshop content that might very well be worth the price depending on who enjoys user-made content.
    [*][u]Camera system needs a re-work[/u]. The camera had a nifty button to let you look up and around, but there is no way to look down. And whenever there's a wall, the camera doesn't clip through the wall and instead stays against the wall, while zooming in way too far. It's easily avoidable by just doing the best you can to avoid moving the cameras around walls, but some areas (like vents or holes in the ground) are very hard to navigate through from the hard-to-see areas.
    [*][u]Janky respawn points[/u]. There are certain areas that require climbing up a large tower or open area, but there were other places to explore below the area that you might currently be in. Getting down there seems to confuse the game into thinking that you fell too far and it will give you "pitfall damage" and respawn you (like you fell into an abyss after missing a jump). This makes traversing some of the areas annoying. Either you are trying to get down to a lower area for a collectible and can't, or doing some platforming from above, fall, and don't respawn back near the top so you have to start over again. These didn't happen often, maybe three times in total during my playthrough, so it's not end-game worthy, but definitely a bit annoying to go through.
[/list]
[h1]Verdict[/h1]
- This game and the DLC is well worth every penny, though maybe get it on sale. It was a delight to play, and I am sad that I didn't play it sooner. There is a huge cult following for this game, and I can see why. It's wonderful, funny, and fun.
- If you are not into collectathons, this game might not be for you, but you might enjoy someone else playing it for the funny story and moments.
- There are also many other things you can do / play with all the Workshop content that's been created, so there are tons of possibilities for everyone to enjoy.

Overall, this game is a dream, everything works with itself to create one the most enticing platformers in recent memory, it never stops being fun, the dialogue is fun, the gameplay is stellar, I listen to the soundtrack non stop, and I was never bored or frustrated with anything, truly a huge achievement, it's one of those games I will never forget and find myself coming back from time to time.
The worst part of the game is the story, which is saying a lot, I never hated what was happening and it kept me engaged, but it's nothing to write home about, it really is just about how fun the characters and character interactions are, making for a still very heartwarming experience.

On top of the base game, the updates and DLC are amazing, the first one (Seal the Deal) continues what was great about the game, and the second one (Nyakuza Metro) somehow improves it by a long shot. The optional Snatcher challenges is where the games gets hard, very, very hard, tight times and fun diverse challenges, and they reward you with many, MANY cosmetics.

143180448.review:
A great nostalgic blast from the N64/Gamecube era! The voice acting is great, but in particular Conductor and Snatcher are stand outs. (I also may be a bit peckin' biased) The developers have gone above and beyond to make sure this game is catered to most skill levels with the absolutely wonderful Assist mode.

The best example is the fact they don't judge you for it. Achievements (if you care about that sort of thing) so far as I know aren't blocked if you enable the mode, and none of the characters give you any sort of hard time about it. The game just adjusts to your skill level. 

This even extends to Death Wish which is enabled through DLC purchasing. If you enable it, some of the contracts are easier (in comparison) and you get all side objective contracts so absolutely none of the content is blocked because the game got too hard. I don't really care for the idea of Death Wish.. but it's there if you care...

If a platforming segment is too hard for you and you find yourself suffering a bit in a fight or just one of the side stuff, Assist will heal you automatically when you stand still for 2 seconds. This is very nice. No judgement, enjoy the game how you want. Games these day make a habit of shaming the player for using an easy mode and this game doesn't judge you at all. It even lets you earn achievements. 

Characters are extremely likable from NPCS to even the main villain of the game. The only sad thing I have discovered is most of the removed content sounds amazing and can be devastating to learn they removed it. This is a wonderful call back to old collectathon platformers in a wonderful heartwarming fashion. From the dev's desire to ensure the game is friendly to any and all skill levels there is literally no reason to not play this game.

The modding scene of this game is also insane and many people create absolutely wonderful mods and levels so be warned that it can take hours of your life if not days checking everything out. If you want to ensure you collect all the collectibles of the game the Radar Hat mod is fun. If you have the DLCS and love the Seals of Seal the Deal.. you can have a Seal on your head. It even prevents you from drowning if you like swimming. Though the game doesn't have a lot of moments where you would need to worry about water. But I love these seals and they are just doing their best. It also acts as a hat that speeds you up on land as well.

With so many options this game easily caters itself to everybody. It's adorable, upbeat, and friendly. Don't do all that well with platformers? This game will cater to that. I beat this game basically about a week and 3 days ago... and I am STILL playing it for mods. It hasn't stopped! I can't stop!!!

142703540.review:
A Hat in Time is an extremely fun & rewarding game to play and I'd seriously recommend it to anyone! It was the first 3D-platforming game that I've played and I constantly had a smile on my face. The characters are endearing & funny and the different chapters are well thought out and are very creative. The OST is one of my favourites, and the game is a good balance between story, fights, and exploration.
If there's any downside to this game, it's that the base game is quite easy (although Seal The Deal definitely makes up for this). This isn't too much of a problem for me as I'm more invested in the characters.
The game runs surprisingly well! My PC runs like a potato and has hardly any free storage space yet it can run AHiT just fine. Changing the quality in the settings in order for your game to run better honestly doesn't really change anything for me in terms of enjoyment.

Seal The Deal is a fun DLC, but I'd only really recommend it if you were bored by how easy the base game was and want a challenge. I wouldn't recommend buying it if you're not planning on doing Death Wish as Chapter 6 is the shortest of the 7 (excluding 5) and doesn't have much to offer. Death Wish is certainly not for the faint hearted and is extremely difficult, but that may be your cup of tea.

Nyakuza Metro has Chapter 7 which is, in my opinion, the best Chapter. It's free roam and has loads to offer, including lots of new badges, weapons, and story. Online Party is the cherry on top for this DLC.

Vanessa's Curse is a fun game mode, but I only recommend getting it if your PC can handle the lag.

Overall, AHiT is an incredibly fun game with endearing characters & story as well as a banger soundtrack. I'd recommend the base game + Nyakuza Metro to anyone, but you may want to look into it further if you're thinking about getting Seal the Deal or Vanessa's Curse. Still, this game will always be one of my favourites. 9/10

142689006.review:
A Hat in Time has quietly worked it's way up to being one of my favorite games of all time.

Its got lovable settings, levels, characters, music, great controls and solid platforming. It can be played in whatever capacity you want. If you want to play casually and sight-see, great! If you want to rip every hair out of your head in frustration at the challenge mode, also great! If you want to goof off with a friend online and play user made levels just to see what people can cook up, also also great! Even after doing a majority of what's available I can still always find a reason to come back, goof off, and enjoy this game in some way or another.

If there is room to complain I will say a few things. The Steam version is THE definitive way to play. Console versions haven't been able to receive a lot of the new content like the new multiplayer mode or the recent winter/summer updates. The fact that the game is still seeing dev support at all is fantastic but the attention is not evenly split among platforms for whatever reason. It is something to look out for if you see this across other platforms and are making a decision among them. The other thing is that the game is a little too honest, so while it's an amazing game if you enjoy platforming, I can't say it would reel you in if that is not the kind of game you usually enjoy. If nothing else it's worth trying out, that much I can say.

If you are looking for a new fun game to dump time into and enjoy a good platformer I highly encourage grabbing this and all it's related DLC while it's on sale. It's worth every penny.

142534799.review:
[h1]This is NOT a collectathon[/h1]
It may appear that way on the outside, but it's a 3D platformer, and it has some of the worst DLC I have ever seen.
Buy this game on sale, not worth full price, same goes for the DLC.

[h1]Collectables[/h1]
After you get all the hats, yarn is pointless to collect.
There's a large variety of cosmetics to unlock through Death Wish stamps, community maps and events, or by finding all the tokens scattered throughout official and community levels.

[h1]DLC[/h1]
There are three DLCs outside of soundtracks:[list]
[*][b]Seal the Deal:[/b]
There are two parts to this, [u]the first part is the Arctic Cruise[/u], which has three acts.
In the second act you have to navigate the cruise ship on a short-of time limit, the cruise ship is a sprawling maze that goes up and down, if you pick the wrong door or the wrong path, you will quickly fail the act.
This goes completely against everything you've done so far in the main game.

[u]The second part is Death Wish[/u], after beating Snatcher you'll be able to get contracts from him, these contracts are an array of challenges ranging from [b]a slight challenge above normal gameplay[/b] to [b]insane masochistic challenge requiring absolute mastery of the game to its very core[/b].
You [b]can[/b] make most of these challenges easier, but to do that you have to fail three times, then you can activate "Peace and Tranquility" mode which honestly should be available by default but is not.

The only stamps you can't enable P&Q for are the candles, all of which are required for the achievement, 3/4 of these are just a fun little scavenger hunt through the chapters. The fourth one is an insane challenge requiring you to finish multiple acts without jumping, to do this you're either going to have to cheat or learn techniques on-par with what speedrunners do.

[*][b]Nyakuza Metro:[/b]
Not bad, pretty fun actually, only thing that sucks is unlike other acts, when you're high up you can't just fall back down, doing so will hurt you and teleport you back up.
To go anywhere else from this point, you either have to collect a time piece or exit to the hub, even after you complete the DLC this is still an issue.

You also get "Online Party" with this, which allows you to play with other people online. Only problem is, without [u]Online Party Plus![/u] from the workshop, you won't see most of other peoples chosen cosmetics.

[*][b]Vanessa's Curse:[/b]
Honestly not worth your time, it's just a PVP mode where you try to collect all the crowns while avoiding infected players.
No achievements are tied to this, its only purpose is cosmetics and playing with strangers, both of which are already avalible through Nyakuza Metro.[/list]

[h1]Bugs[/h1]
If you get all Deathwish stamps and have a mods with stamps or there's an event going on with stamps, you won't unlock the achievement.
Only way to fix this is to disable both of the previously mentioned, reset one of you finished stamps and finish it again, then  your achievement will unlock.

141958730.review: A Hat in Time is an amazingly polished game for a developer's first game and doubly so for a genre that is notoriously hard to develop for. Controls are tight and responsive, characters are unique and memorable, and worlds while clearly taking inspiration from older 3D platformers are outside the default set of level tropes. 141594598.review:
as someone who hasn't played a lot of 3D mario-esque games i must say I had a blast playing this game. The controls take a bit of getting used to but once you're used to them they're like second nature. gameplay is incredibly fun. and if you care about story, it's pretty good as well, i even caught myself invested in it a couple of times, though most of the fun is in the gameplay. 
now, it's not a perfect game by any stretch of the meaning, the movement is smooth and engaging, but it does get a little frustrating in certain cases. most probably to the 3D camera's fault, granted it could just be a me issue since I'm not really an experienced 3D mario-esque player, but there are a lot of times when the camera angle gets in a very awkward position while you're platforming, making an otherwise smooth movement experience really frustrating. especially when you're trying to make an accurate jump but fail to judge the distance and end up missing your jump, oftentimes falling to your death (do note that i was playing this on a controller, i imagine it's vastly easier to control the camera with a mouse). those may be the only times when it's not entirely the player's fault for failing. apart from that the difficulty is satisfying. it's neither too easy, nor overbearingly hard. The game doesn't feel unfair when you mess up, and if you're an average gamer you likely won't have too big of a trouble beating levels, but there will be challenge, resulting in a fairly balanced difficulty to fun ratio. 
overall it's a solid 8/10 game, I've 100%-ed it because of how fun it is, including all the DLC's that matter (nyakuza). I only wish there was more of it.

141408433.review:
Bought the Ultimate Edition and played through it all on the Steam Deck.

I loved Super Mario Sunshine and Super Mario Odyssey for their open design and movement system that made the game as difficult as I wanted it to be. Hat in Time was on my radar for a while and decided to go for it to scratch that itch for another fun 3D platformer.

Going in I expected to have some fun with a decent movement system and not much more, but WOW this game gave me more than I had bet on! The characters, level design, and creative concepts packed into this game really blew me away, very memorable in the same way as Phsyconauts. Nothing life changing here, but so many moments that felt wonderfully funny and entertaining. 

Movement in Hat in Time is great as well, forgiving but still very fun and satisfying to execute more complex combos and a decent amount of depth and nuance to the basic moves. Definitely scratched that itch and found myself trying to perform moves from this game when I hopped back into Super Mario Odyssey.

This game can also be very visually pretty with some really elaborate and fantastical level design. If this game suffers from anything it would be perhaps that it sometimes tries to do too much at once and can either be confusing or easy to forget a mechanic or story beat that was previously established. A few times I found myself going into levels and or cutscenes and not understanding what was really happening until the end of it. This issue however is a the best one to have and after a full play through I'm excited to jump back in and experience it all again.

Hat in Time is jam packed and filled to the brim and beyond with fantastic ideas and fun, it gets my easy recommendation.

141328394.review:
The game's highs are high but the lows are lows. Love the music, presentation, voice acting and general cuteness of the game. The game seems to stutter slightly as it loads certain levels but otherwise plays fine. The lows are, some levels objectives are quite dull. There is little hand holding which some may say is a good thing but I found myself wandering aimlessly in many places. No mini map is quite annoying for large levels such as chapter 4. Character and platform collision feels very inexact, often leading to unfair deaths. The camera can also fight against the player as it collides into walls or gets far too cramped to the player character. Boss battles can feel cheap, often ending with do or die situations with little hints on what to do to proceed, often requiring a complete restart of the boss battle.

I recommend it with caution. The overall game is cute, but the gameplay itself can be somewhat frustrating, but good.

The hat and badge mechanics aren't complex enough to facilitate any type of real puzzle-solving, but simultaneously too cumbersome to be fun to combine on the fly.

Do you like going into the menus to enable sprinting? Do you enjoy equipping an item every time you want to use the grappling hook? If not, you'll probably just keep the same few abilities equipped all of the time, which begs the question why these basic features weren't just enabled to begin with, or unlocked permanently once you got them.

To play "optimally", of course, you'd disable the grappling hook every time you aren't grappling, and replace it with one of the other passive abilities. Or one of the more creative abilities you might actually want to experiment with. But that means going back into the menus the next time you encounter an obstacle you need one of the more important abilities for. It's not just the grappling hook, all the abilities in the game follow this logic. It's a mystery to me how no one during development recognized this as a fundamentally bad design choice.

141012457.review:
I adore 3D platformers, and A Hat in Time may well be the exemplar of its genre. To me, 3D platformers need 3 things above all else: a strong personality, satisfying/addictive movement, and a banger soundtrack. A Hat in Time excels in all of these areas. The writing is charming and adorable, but also sharp and sometimes delightfully off-beat. The game conveys its setting and tells its story with impeccable flair. Most impressive is the sheer variety of stuff to do; every level feels completely distinct and memorable, even within the same world, and the vast majority of the game's "gimmicks" feel as polished and fun as the main gameplay itself. In this aspect, A Hat in Time outdoes even distinguished big franchises like Mario.

I don't have much criticism for the game, though I suppose my biggest one is that it's pretty short, even with the DLC. There are only 4 worlds in the base game, 2 more with the DLC for a total of 6. Also - and this is PC-specific - optimization and stability can suffer especially with mods. The game takes a very long time to start up, often needs to be force-closed, and I've run into problems with sound output as well as stuttering in-game. (These problems don't exist on console, but the mods are really half the fun, so you want to play on PC if you can.) Luckily, none of these problems affect the actual playing experience. But they do impact the overall sense of polish.

Overall, this is one of the most delightful games you'll ever play. I can't get enough of it, and I hope we get more.

tl;dr: PECK

140506429.review:
A hat in time, ¿Por donde empezar?

Me parece grandioso como juegos de la antigua época como lo fue Super Mario 64 o Banjo Kazooie terminen influenciando de buena forma en juegos actuales de la industria.

Este juego se nos presenta como un plataformas 3D que toma los conceptos de los juegos mencionados previamente y los expande para construir su propio mundo.

El diseño de niveles está tan bien construido que te da un pequeño viaje de nostalgia, cada zona que visitas de alguna u otra forma está conectado con otro mundo y eso esta bastante bien porque no puedes pasar el juego de una manera que digas "Haré todo en orden".

Esto debido a que ciertos objetos que consigues en ciertos mundos son clave para ciertos niveles.

Los personajes, bromas e incluso el voice acting hace que la experiencia de juego sea más enriquecedora, habrán personajes que te caerán mejor que otros por sus personalidades pero bueno, tiene que funcionar de esa forma.

El gameplay me parece glorioso, el personaje se controla bastante bien y como dije, al estar jugando al juego notaras muchos guiños a Super Mario 64 (Hasta en el DLC tienen una skin retro de ese estilo.)

La banda sonora es brutal, no hay ningún solo tema que no me gustase de este juego. Cada tema va concorde a la situación que estas experimentando dentro del juego y eso es simplemente magnifico. 

A Hat in time es uno de esos juegos que mucha gente debe de darle una oportunidad, vale totalmente la pena las horas invertidas y te divertirás bastante. Su historia podrá ser cliche pero hay lore oculto de cada uno de los personajes que vale la pena de echarle una mirada.

Recomendado al 100%

Cute but buggy. 
Some achievements and Death Wishes are nearly impossible, even harder than some cuphead levels, because at least cuphead is pattern based, whereas there was multiple times where I nearly won and then the character glitched or the game just froze all together.  There was a point where after doing parkour for over an hour my character got stuck into the ground and I had to reset and lose all my progress for that map. 
There is an assist mode which helps with some but honestly just makes it TOO easy and there is no real way to save other than collecting a new time piece or quitting and reopening so if you have to reset you're kinda screwed. 
The humor is very 2015/Undertale/UwUxD which I understand is to be expected from a 2017 game but I did cringe a couple times. 

Overall a fun game that's difficult to master but easy to love. I would recommend it,  but if you are planning on trying to 100% it prepare to ragequit

139278614.review:
Great game with an amazing and welcoming community. 

You play as a kid, with a hat. She's an alien, but that's besides the point. You go through missions in 1. A Mafia Island, 2. Bird Hollywood, 3. Spooky Legally Binding Forest, 4.Dangerous Mountains with even more dangerous accents, and 5. Bowser's Castle. There's several Time Pieces, which are kinda like Mario 64 stars that unlock new areas of the map. There's also time rifts which are hidden throughout the levels that give you a time piece and some lore if you look in the purple ones.  Lots of other collectibles which unlock different stuff in the game that changes up the experience or lets you dress up.

You'll traverse the world through the use of Hats, which are abilities you can switch between whenever you need them. Each one serves its own purpose. There's a lot of fun to be had in the game, and it feels nice whenever you unlock a new thing or progress in the game. The little stories each area tells is really entertaining and engaging.

Definitely get the DLC since Nyakuza Metro + Vanessa's Curse (aka Crime Lord Cat + Horror Hide and Seek) adds online mode where you can play along with friends and mess around with new ones! Not like buying one or both of the soundtracks and the Seal the Deal + Death Wish (aka Seal Titanic + Hard Mode Challenges) is any worse, just saying that one offers the biggest upgrade.

 Also there's a Steam Workshop that is bustling with amazing creations! Buy it, it's half the price of a modern triple a game and with more than twice the charm.

TLDR: Dis gaem gud, pls buy.

139241719.review:
I tried this game years back but the first world seemed kinda slow. I wish I'd given it more of a chance sooner because it recently became one of my favourite games ever. 

The game has a really positive, cheerful vibe to the whole thing. Although with a bit of an edge if that's the right word for it.It has a kind of sarcastic and random humor I enjoy, but the story still takes itself fairly seriously at times. Just a pretty good balance, with characters I really grew to like and wanted to find out what happens next.

 It's 100% it's own game but has enough design throwbacks to the games it was based off of to feel right at home with them. A Hat in Time definitely isn't perfect though, there's some kinda odd game design choices here and there. Chapter 4's open world felt sort of unpolished and like in Mario 64, the frustrating camera can add to the difficulty of the platforming. 

It's really nice to have a game where I can just relax, collect some stuff and not worry too much lol

Sin duda, cómpralo, no puedo decir más. Soy muy selectivo con los juegos y siempre busco que tengan mucho contenido, incluso "infinito". 138984723.review:
It's a decent 3D platformer, but it's also massively overhyped, and is more focused on a cutesy presentation than compelling gameplay.  Granted, that's not necessarily a bad thing depending on who you ask, but for me, most of the levels were very average aside from the last one, which was by far the best.

Also the game is way more influenced by Super Mario Sunshine than the wild variety of 3D platformers that people regularly compare it to.  For example, it really doesn't play anything like the Banjo games despite that being the most common comparison.  Again, not necessarily a bad thing depending on who you ask, but I don't think people remember Banjo very well if they think A Hat in Time is even remotely similar to it, aside from them both being collectathons.

That being said, I wouldn't really recommend *against* it.  It's obviously a good game with a good level of polish...But is it the masterpiece people say it is?  Ehh, not really.  It's just another 3D platformer.

138886564.review:
It's the return of the 3D collectathon platformer! 
A Hat in Time is very much inspired by games such as Banjo-Kazooie and Super Mario Sunshine, and fans of those games will really enjoy this new take on the classic early 3D platformer. Being a collectathon, A Hat in Time has several important trinkets to collect that let you progress to new levels, and gain new Hats which give you special moves, such as an ice ground-pound or the ability to dash. 
The biggest issue with this game is that it inherits the boot-out system from Super Mario 64 and Sunshine, but this is made up for by having levels drastically change with each revisit. 
If you long for early 3D platformers, this is a fantastic new take that shouldn't be missed out on.

138626533.review:
An alright game if you're looking for a relatively easy, casual collectathon. I appreciate how they tried to make each chapter feel unique, but the deviations in mechanics sometimes got in the way of the fun (chapter 2 in particular felt like a slog).

At first I was excited for the hat / powers mechanic but most of the hats aren't very interesting. The default hat points you to your objective, the brewing hat is basically just used to destroy crates, and for the ice hat you just press the button when you're standing on an ice pad to access a previously inaccessible area. They can be used in combat but there's not really a point since it's more efficient to just attack or evade enemies. That leaves just the sprint hat and the dweller's mask (and the late game time stop hat), which I do like, but there's not much variety in cool powers.

The game in general is very easy with most platforms and balloons being perfectly spaced out so you don't have to think about jumping or do any partial jumps. The paths you're supposed to take are laid out with green gems. The puzzles are very simple for the most part as well. I just got to chapter 4 (of 5) and the difficulty has finally started to step up a little. What's weird is the bosses seem to be pretty big difficulty spikes. I've only completed the first and third chapter's bosses but they were both significantly harder than any of the other platforming so far. I really enjoyed them, I just wish the rest of the game wasn't such a breeze. I thought the "time rift" side-missions would be like some optional, more difficult levels but they're just as easy and kind of repetitive in that a lot of them reuse the same platforms in the same ways.

An easy difficulty isn't necessarily a bad thing. Mario Odyssey was easy, but the difference is that game had really tight, satisfying controls that let you do some crazy shit. It had a low skill floor for accessibility and a high skill ceiling if you wanted to pull off fun stunts and speedrun the maps. The mechanics in A Hat in Time are simplistic: you have a double jump, a wall climb, a wall jump, and a slide that you can cancel out of mid-air. Also a crawl that you almost never need to use. There's not a lot of fun with traversal because it feels automatic. Obviously comparing a AAA game with a Kickstarter game isn't much of a fair comparison, but I'm trying to say that without the difficulty, I need something else to be satisfied by with the gameplay, otherwise I'm just going to be bored.

The camera is pretty awful, which is my biggest beef with A Hat in Time and the reason I ultimately stopped playing. It will zoom in way too close for no apparent reason, usually when you're next to walls, which is when I want it zoomed out so I can see the terrain around me. The camera pan is a single button press that only looks upward and only lasts a couple seconds. It would've been way better to have a toggle like the first person view of Mario 64 (or similar). The manual camera controls don't fix the camera's issues either.

I wanted to like this game but after 8 hours I realized I just wasn't having much fun.

[h1]My Rating: 2/5[/h1]

138570888.review:
A Hat in Time was a game that I had slept on once it came some years ago. It came and went, but had certainly left an impact on many people. Finally, with a sale and an itch to play something in the genre, I secured a copy and played through it.

For one, the art style and music are both rather charming, but I feel neither left much of an impact on me. The kid, the protagonist, also didn't leave much of an impression though I did like the small moments she had in cutscenes.

The gameplay, for the most part, is good. The game is responsive enough and movement feels delightful. However, there is a small wall run you can do to try and reach higher platforms. I found the MC's feet were like magnets and, sometimes brushing up against a wall, would lock her in this option even if you didn't mean to. With that said, the gameplay loop is simple, but effective. Finding the McGuffin (time pieces) until you've done the checklist, then beat the boss of the level. Rinse and repeat. Nothing groundbreaking, but solid.

The worlds, I found, to be a mixed bag. On one hand, I found them to be quite nice and pleasant to traverse a bit. However, I found that they lacked much in terms of landmarks. Typically, a game would have some recognizable areas or landmarks which make traversal easier. However, I found the levels lacked this and became a bit hard to navigate, especially the third level. Again, with that said, they were small enough to not become too troublesome.

In terms of story, there really isn't much of one, and what is there I think you could do without. It was okay overall, but didn't think it added much...but with that said, I understand it to be a reason for the game to happen, so I don't mind in the end.

The game is short enough if going to 100%, about a little over 8 hours for me, which is pretty nice. However, I do think the game's price is a little steep for what it is. If you can find the game on a sale of some sort, absolutely pick it up and enjoy a little gem from a few years back. But, if not, I'd say to pick it up if you're really interested. I found the game to be good, but also think there's better out there for the price. With that said, if you still decide to pick it up, it's a game that, while not fully complex, still leaves a good enough impression on you.

137917420.review:
"A Hat in Time is like a delightful and colorful dream that you never want to wake up from.

As the player, you'll find yourself playing as a cute little girl with a big hat, who's on a mission to collect magical hourglasses scattered throughout various whimsical worlds. And let me tell you, nothing feels more satisfying than jumping around and solving puzzles with the power of hats.

But beware, because the virtual world is full of enemies, like evil birds and creepy mafia guys who will stop at nothing to get in your way.

Of course, the game isn't perfect. Sometimes it feels like you're stuck in a never-ending cycle of jumping and hatting and jumping and hatting and jumping...

But despite its flaws, A Hat in Time is a charming and addictive game that will have you grinning from ear to ear.

So if you're looking for a game that will transport you to a magical world of hats and hourglasses, give A Hat in Time a try. Just don't forget to tip your hat to the virtual princesses."

137839121.review:
A Hat in Time follows Hat Kid, a little alien girl wearing a top hat trying to return to her home world via spaceship. While on her journey, she passes over a planet, and a member of the planet's Mafia comes to collect a toll for the Mafia Town government. When Hat Kid refuses to pay, the Mafia man busts the spaceship door open, causing Hat Kid and all of her "Time Pieces", magical hourglasses that power her ship, to fall to the planet below. Hat Kid lands in Mafia Town and meets Mustache Girl, a local troublemaker who hates "bad guys". Mustache Girl agrees to look for the missing Time Pieces in exchange for Hat Kid's help fighting the Mafia, and the two defeat the Mafia Boss. When Mustache Girl realizes the Time Pieces can rewind time, she wants to use them to become a time-traveling superhero, but Hat Kid refuses, as she is aware that messing with time is dangerous. Angered by this refusal, Mustache Girl declares the two enemies and sets off to find the Time Pieces on her own.

Hat Kid ventures across the planet looking for Time Pieces, encountering and befriending many foes that included two rival bird directors DJ Grooves and the Conductor competing for a movie award in a movie studio called Dead Bird Studio and a group of mountain villagers called Nomads infected by a dangerous plague, ultimately befriending them all. Hat Kid also outwits a malevolent spirit called the Snatcher into becoming her best friend after he temporarily stole her soul, tricked her into doing his dirty work in Subcon Forest, and attempted to murder Hat Kid. The game's DLCs have Hat Kid searching for Time Pieces while working in an ocean liner called the Arctic Cruise owned by the Walrus Captain and under the employ of the Nyakuza crime boss called the Empress in an underground city called Nyakuza Metro, the latter ending with Hat Kid being forced to flee the city after a bounty was placed on her head. Mustache Girl exploits Hat Kid's absence to break into her ship and steals the collected Time Pieces, using them to turn the planet into a fiery inferno where her word is law. Hat Kid confronts her, but Mustache Girl uses the Time Pieces to open a time rift and make herself all-powerful.

The enemies Hat Kid has fought come to her aid in battle, some sacrificing themselves so that Hat Kid can use their dropped Heart Pons (the healing collectible) to power herself up. Hat Kid finally defeats Mustache Girl and uses the Time Pieces to reset the timeline, restoring the planet to normal and reviving all those who were lost. The player can then choose whether Hat Kid should hand over a Time Piece to Mustache Girl (so she can defeat the Mafia and free her town from their control as was her desire in the beginning of the game) or not. Though her former foes are sad to see her leave, Hat Kid restores the Time Pieces to her vault and resumes her voyage home. In a post-credits scene, Hat Kid is shown sleeping in bed surrounded by toys resembling the other characters.

137316530.review:
"A Hat in Time" is a platformer game that promises a lot, but ultimately falls short of expectations. While the game has a charming aesthetic with bright colors and whimsical characters, it fails to deliver in terms of gameplay.

The controls are clunky and imprecise, making it difficult to perform basic movements like jumping and running. The camera is also a major issue, often getting stuck or positioned in a way that makes it difficult to navigate through the levels.

Additionally, the game's levels lack variety and quickly become repetitive. The puzzles are uninspired and the enemies are generic and uninteresting. The story is also lacking, with a forgettable plot that fails to engage the player.

Overall, "A Hat in Time" is a disappointing game that fails to live up to its potential. It's not worth the time or money invested in it, and there are much better platformers out there that offer a more engaging and rewarding experience.

Really fun Hat collecting game, though for a Team Fortress 2 spinoff, there are not enough guns.

Edit. Now that I played some more, let's be serious. The game is fun to play and entertaining but has one big flaw. The camera. It's one of the worse cameras I had to use in a game. It's far too close, and even worse, it tends to come even closer, during some platforming, that the kid takes most of the space on the screen. You can't tilt it up, so trying to see platforms or collectibles that are above you, borders on impossible (really detrimental in the Mafia Town). Some sections, like the mushroom tree in the Subcon could use a fixed camera following the kid around the trunk. All in all, it's not atrocious, but it is bad.

136616401.review:
One of my favourite games -- wrestling for a top-10 spot right now. An absolute love-letter to a bygone era of collectathons and a brilliant amalgamation of their unique highlights, lovingly-crafted as a tribute to each in a small way, pulled together into a cohesive ball of creativity and solid kinetic feel-good motion.

And then you unlock Death Wish, and prepare for the most grueling, sadistically crafted challenge in any 3D platformer. And I love it to death... wish. I've got a soft-spot the size of Isle Delfino for Master Quest style hard modes in games, and Death Wish delivers like the best of them. Remixed missions and challenges and bosses coming off the already wonderfully creative world just means a new, more focused angle to appreciate it all from, assuming this brand of self-inflicted torture is your kind of thing. Just remember that the tools the game offers for you are all intended ways to play. No shame in taking the Peace and Tranquility route just to unlock stuff, even though you might, like me, consider it a matter of personal accomplishment to not have.

Add onto all this the extreme level of mod support -- including a few that I would consider essential from go for a more solid experience (Diary+ and Death Wish Ultimate especially) -- and good-natured cutting humour, and you've got yourself one of the most fun, charming, and addictive games in the genre. Snatcher is bae don't @ me

136432171.review:
I'll start with what everyone already knows: This game is cute-as-heck. Everything screams "cute" and "adorable".

The gameplay is very smooth, even though at first it's very hard to control Hat Kid, you get used to how jumping changes the direction you're facing, and start to make some pretty sick moves.
The game is heavilly inspired by Nintendo platformers, like Mario Galaxy. You'll find a lot of similarities, like the areas of the ship, that is it's version of the observatories, the Time Pieces that are the Power Stars and even the galaxies, that the game referes to chapters.

The story is very simple and easy to understand. It kinda sounds like something Nintendo would come up with! The characters are charismatic, unique and interesting, although simple, they fill their role in the plot and are very different from one another.

Even though the game is very simple in terms of graphics and art stile, it's still kinda difficult to make it run smoothilly even with the graphics setings that you can change. I experienced a lot of FPS drops and slowness every time I enter a chapter. Notable situations are the Nyakuza Metro on it's entirety and the final act of Arctic Cruise.

Overall, it's a very creative game, that's very nostalgic to some because of it's inspiration on games like Mario, and a very good start for those who never played a platform before. Very good for casual players, but for those who want a chalange, the mod scene of the game gives plenty of options to choose from.

[h1] It's a must buy I LOVE THIS GAME  [/h1]

If you're looking for a charming and delightful 3D-platformer, look no further than "A Hat In Time." This game is a true gem that you won't want to miss out on. It's even more fun with a friend (of course :D) I mean who doesn't want to beat up his friend and do a smug face after that? XD

From the moment you start playing, you'll be transported to a colorful world that's full of personality and charm. The game has a unique style that's both cute and silly, making it a joy to explore.

What really sets A Hat In Time apart from other 3D-platformers is its creativity. The game offers a fresh and unique experience that will keep you engaged and entertained for hours on end. The levels are well-designed, and the puzzles are clever and challenging.

Despite its few shortcomings (a few bugs and sometimes the camera is a bit weird), the game's controls are smooth and the characters are incredibly lovable. You'll quickly fall in love with the game's protagonist, Hat Kid, and her quirky cast of supporting characters.

If you're a fan of classic 3D-platformers like Super Mario, then you MUST give this game a try. It's the perfect game to scratch that nostalgic itch while still offering a new and refreshing experience.

In short, "A Hat In Time" is a wonderful game that you won't want to miss out on. Its charming characters, creative levels, and solid gameplay make it a must-play for any fan of 3D-platformers. So stop reading reviews and start playing the game – you won't regret it! :3

135864699.review:
No sabría por donde empezar... que NO lo recomiendo es algo clarísimo, es malo en todos los sentidos.

Como juego de plataformas es una basura con un conjunto de movimientos limitados. De hecho, sólo tiene el doble salto y un dash hacia adelante; intenta complementar esa limitación con la mecánica de los sombreros, que en realidad son otros movimientos básicos del género que se podrían realizar igualmente con diferentes botones, pero que está implementado así para que tengas que ponerte el sombrerito de turno y justificar esta mecánica. Así lo único que se obtiene es una sensación de barrera entre el usuario y el juego, y pérdida de dinamismo en la jugabilidad.

El diseño de niveles es nefasto: no son divertidos ni invitan a la exploración, y la recompensa por un área de plataformeo o un "puzle", es un ítem para canjear diseños de sombreros o cosméticos.

No termina de establecer un lenguaje propio, por lo que a veces no sabes qué es exactamente lo que tienes que hacer, quizás en parte porque trata de ser un sucedáneo barato de Mario Galaxy hasta puntos alarmantes. El sistema de la nave central, entrar a los niveles como si fueran planetas, hasta la animación de coger los relojes, los sonidos, algunas áreas de plataformeo... Sin embargo, no es más que eso, un cascarón sin alma. La protagonista no trasmite ninguna empatía y la historia es absurda, no es que de este tipo de juegos se espere una novela, pero esto parece estar escrito en una mañana y con desgana.

La variedad de enemigos es escasa y con mecánicas simples o directamente estáticas. Los jefes finales, repetitivos y nada originales.

Ahora llegamos al punto fuerte, la cámara; es una locura, es como si la hubieran diseñado odiándote, quiere quitarte los deseos de jugar a este juego a toda costa. En sitios cerrados te hace un zoom y lo único que ves es la cabeza del personaje, y en lugares abiertos con desniveles tratas de girarla y se bloquea verticalmente, en mitad de plataformeo se gira sola.

El juego es muy corto, y el contenido adicional (previo pago) no merece la pena, es ampliar la sensación de desidia que produce jugarlo.

Mi género favorito son los plataformas 2D y 3D: he completado Cuphead, The Messenger, Yooka Laylee, Monsterboy, Spyro... con todos los logros, es decir, que no escribo estas líneas porque piense que sea difícil; es malo, profundamente malo, créeme cuando te digo que es de lo peor que he jugado en mi vida.

NO lo compres salvo que quieras perder las ganas de vivir. Si te lo regala alguien replantéate esa amistad, quizás no te quiera tanto. No pierdas un minuto jugando este juego clónico, sin espíritu y que intenta imitar a los grandes del género.
